6« In the United States people tend to listen or view stations for the
following reasons in the following order of importance.
a) Strength or accessibility of signal of the station, e.g.
ease and clarity with which one station is received as op¬
posed to another. (This factor has special application in
terns of UHF transmitters in VHF areas.)
b) Frequency of the program. All other things being equal, a
fairly good program or even a poor program has a better chance
of acceptance if it is heard five times a week rather than
once; once per week rather than once per month; once per
month rather than once per year.
e) The program itself.
These factors apparently do not prevail to the same extent on the Continent.
People do not devote as much time to looking and listening asrthey do in the
United States. The factor of competition between stations for the listening-
viewing Attention of the individual is not the same major factor.
In the United States, however, any station must be on the air at regu3a r times,
often enough, and long enough to create a habit of listening and looking. As one
individual at the University of Michigan said a long time ago, nthe university
must present programs when the people wish to listen, not when the University
wants them to listen".
If one agrees cm these propositions, a conzaon concept of educators about tele¬
vision is iranediately rendered absurd—namely, the idea of an educational tele¬
vision station being on the air only two or three hours a week (if that is the
maximum amount of quality programs it can produce) • First, no one can predict¬
ably write masterpieces* secondly, the practical effect of such a policy is for
the station to completely escape public attention or have to spend time and
money in promoting audience attention to its "special occasional features" com¬
pletely but of proportion to its budget. (The best "premotion" is the continued
presence of the station itself with frequent programs which approach, if they
do not begin to reach, the "ideal standard").
Obviously educators are primarily concerned with "the program itself" and they
regard these other matters as of minor or passing importance. However, having
embarked on station operation, the university finds itself in the midst of a very
complex activity, no portion of which can be neglected. It is one thing for the
University of Chicago to air a single program on NBC where myriad member stations
through their 18 hour per day transmitter operations and through days and weeks
of presentation of other programs provide a vehicle for airing the Chicago
University program to a ready-made audience. It is another matter for that
university to assume the obligation of building and operating a station which
must carry on the whole business of transmitter operation and maintenance and sus¬
tain a schedule of programs of many kinds prior to presentation of the one-time
apiece de resistance" the University especially values.
A college information service can fancy itself in the newspaper business through
its system of press releases, but it does not have the trying necessity of operating
printing presses, collecting news, laying out pages, maintaining a circulation
department, etc., which a newspaper faces. Actually, the information service
has taken a "free ride" on an already established channel of conuiunication.
